questions.text: A patient is undergoing neurosurgery under general anaesthesia. Before extubation the anaesthetist wants to check recovery from neuromuscular blockade. Which of these nerves is most commonly monitored for the same?

  • • most commonly monitored
  • • assessing recovery
  • • neuromuscular blockade
  • • Consistency in Responses : The adductor pollicis muscle , innervated by the ulnar nerve , is more sensitive to neuromuscular blocking agents than other muscles. This makes it a good choice for monitoring neuromuscular blockade and ensuring complete reversalbefore extubation . Ease of Monitoring : The ulnar nerve is easily accessible at the wrist , and the thumb's movement (adduction) against resistance can be readily observed and felt . The setup for monitoring using a peripheral nerve stimulator is straightforward. Minimal Interference : Monitoring at the ulnar nerve has minimal interference from surrounding muscles and structures. This provides a clear assessment of the blockade's depth and recovery . Reliable Predictive Value : The degree of neuromuscular blockade at the adductor pollicis muscle ( innervated by the ulnar nerve ) is more indicative of blockade in the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles , which are critical for effective breathing and airway protection post-extubation . While other nerves can also be used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade, the ulnar nerve's advantages make it the preferred choice in many clinical scenarios, especially for ensuring safe extubation in neurosurgery patients .
